title: 107_s2755
content:
The Act may be cited as the "National Constitution Center Commemorative Coin Act of 2002". Congress finds that a Constitutional Convention was convened in 1787 in Philadelphia to replace the Articles of Confederation, leading to the creation of the United States Constitution. The Constitution drew upon the experiences of ancient Greece and other nations to form a representative government. The Bill of Rights in the United States Constitution is a strong set of legal protections for individual rights, serving as a benchmark for human rights standards globally. The Constitution's principles have influenced laws in many countries and are reflected in the founding documents of the United Nations. The Constitution established the framework for the world's oldest representative democracy and allows for amendments to improve and update it. The National Constitution Center was established in 1988 to interpret and promote understanding of the United States Constitution. The Constitution's principles continue to attract people worldwide to the freedoms it guarantees. The National Constitution Center in Philadelphia is the only center in the world solely dedicated to promoting understanding of the Constitution and its values. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS.

The Secretary of the Treasury shall mint and issue $1 silver coins weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, containing 90% silver and 10% copper. These coins will be legal tender.

SEC. 4. SOURCES OF BULLION.

The Secretary may obtain silver for minting coins from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act and other available sources if needed.

SEC. 5. DESIGN OF COINS. SEC. 5. DESIGN OF COINS. The coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the National Constitution Center in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, with inscriptions of value, year, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with advisory committees. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a single United States Mint facility starting January 1, 2003, until the quantity limit is reached. The coins minted under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. Surcharges will apply to all sales of coins issued under this Act. Surcharges for coins issued under this Act will be set by the Secretary, not exceeding $10 per coin. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. The proceeds from surcharges on coins minted under this Act will be promptly paid to the National Constitution Center for promoting understanding of the Constitution. The Comptroller General can audit the Center's expenditures. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure minting coins won't cost the government. Payment for coins requires full payment, security, or a guarantee from a depository institution.
